On SWIM

349 words written on Wed, Aug 10 2005

It was actually while looking at the Technorati info on SWIM that I thought about this page‚Äôs sidebar link/blurb on SWIM. ‚ÄúWTF does SWIM have to do with nonlinear anything?‚Äù I hear nonexistant readers asking.

SWIM the web CMS is the first baby step towards SWIM the nonlinear mind mapping slash organization slash CMS tool.

Eating lots of my own dog food this morning with a fresh install of SWIM destined for danielsjourney.com (sometime in the next century), I realized that SWIM is pretty damn impressive.

One feature (and I‚Äôll get to how this links to future SWIM nonlinear goodness later) that was a pain to develop, but that I like alot, is the ability to linearly display the taxonomy. Other CMS‚Äôs can do this too, I know, but it‚Äôs a built-in characteristic of SWIM.

Here‚Äôs an example display of a taxonomy in a typical outline format:

Here‚Äôs the display of an entry-specific taxonomy in a linear format:

‚Ä¶indicating the tree structure of the entries existence in one category and the stand-aloneness of another category.

Now where this will get cool sometime in the next decade (or much sooner, god willing) (investors, anyone?) (just kidding) (no i‚Äôm not) ‚Ä¶is where there will be meaning links between not only categories in the taxonomy, but between individual entries. Then SWIM can start doing creative analytics on your entries and suggesting interconnected meanings between entries. Something akin to this, but, you know, much more useful (Upon request for the info: ‚ÄúThis entry may relate to: x, y, and z‚Äù).

For now, we need to get some basic CMS features released, and again not to gush but I am really happy with the way we‚Äôve made a lot of these basic CMS features work already. We‚Äôre talking in depth about how to get a tagging system working in SWIM, and then make it work intuitively/seemlessly with our existing taxonomy system, and how to make it then work with the future ‚Äúmeaning tags/links‚Äù system.
